byline.contributor: Matt Apuzzo reported from Washington, and Timothy Williams from New York. Alan Blinder contributed reporting from Charleston, S.C.
byline.original: By MATT APUZZO and TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

abstract: Recent rise in video recordings by private citizens of police encounters, like that of white Police Officer Michael T Slager killing unarmed black man Walter L Scott in North Charleston, SC, reignites calls for more officers to wear cameras; sometimes-grisly cellphone videos call into question just how much American criminal justice system can rely on police officers' version of events.
lead_paragraph: Videos of police shootings have spurred calls for more officers to use cameras, raising questions about how much the justice system can rely on the accounts of police officers.

headline.main: Video of Walter Scott Shooting Reignites Debate on Police Tactics
headline.print_headline: Citizen's Videos Raise Questions on Police Claims
